poemContent: Earth and Bones, old sticks and stones, Just one long road to Al'mogus. Sandles, seared by the sun-struck path, oh how I wish I had taken the car. All for a land, oh so, so far. Struggling to Al'mogus. A vulture, flew overhead, then dropped down dead! Beating my back like a brick of lead. Yet I Shouted 'horay', meat for days! On my way to Al'mogus. Fingers blue and black, have left the track. A new track of red, and filled with dread, I finally fall, and smash my head, I start dreaming about Al'mogus. A winding road once lead to a land a far, of wealth and riches, gold and cars. Yet barren bodies of idiots lined it's paths, An American dream of Al'mogus. 
